courseTitle: The Effect of pH on Microbial Growth

pageData.titleName2: The Effect of pH on Microbial Growth

pageData.text: Microbes are able to survive in a wide range of environments. One of the factors that can influence growth is the level of acidity, or . The pH of the environment can range from to . Microbes can be found in both alkaline and acidic conditions. Some are , which have adapted to acidic conditions, while others are , which have adapted to live under alkaline conditions. Most cellular microbes are and live at a near pH. This investigation will address the ability of microbes to adapt to changing pH conditions. The growth of the microbes will reflect their ability to cope with changes in acidity.

pageData.text: Microbes live in all kinds of extreme environments – those with high salinity, boiling temperatures, low <button class='glossary-text'>pH</button>, etc. Those that live in low pH, or <button class='glossary-text'>acidic</button>, environments are part of our everyday lives, often appearing in food stuffs such as yogurt, pickles, tempeh, or kombucha. These microbes are widespread across the culinary landscape because they are helpful bacteria, or probiotics, that aid digestion. There is another acid-loving microbe, however, that is less beneficial to our digestive systems.

Helicobacter pylori is a type of bacteria that infects the stomach and small intestine. Although you can have the bacteria and not show symptoms, H. pylori can cause open sores in the upper digestive tract, called peptic ulcers, and even stomach cancer1. It is still a common misconception that stress or certain foods are responsible for ulcers; in reality, it is often an H. pylori infection breaking down the protective stomach lining, causing stomach acid to damage the stomach lining2.

1John Hopkins Medicine. (2023). Helicobacter Pylori. Health.
https://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/health/conditions-and-diseases/helicobacter-pylori2NHS. (20 February 2023). Stomach ulcer. NHS Inform. https://www.nhsinform.scot/illnesses-and-conditions/stomach-liver-and-gastrointestinal-tract/stomach-ulcer

pageData.text: One of the environmental factors that can influence microbial growth is . This is an indication of the concentration of hydrogen ions (H+) in an aqueous solution (a solution in which water is the solvent). The pH is calculated by taking the negative logarithm (base 10) of the molar concentration (moles/liter) of H+: pH = – log10 [H+]

The pH scale goes from 0, extremely <button class='glossary-text'>acidic</button>, to 14, which is extremely <button class='glossary-text'>alkaline</button>, or <button class='glossary-text'>basic</button>. A pH of 7 is considered <button class='glossary-text'>neutral</button> (Figure 1). At pH 7, the concentrations of H<sup>+</sup> and hydroxide ions (OH<sup>-</sup>) released by the constant dissociation of water molecules are equally balanced. Pure water has a pH of 7. The addition of other chemicals to water can cause the pH to fall or rise, depending on whether H<sup>+</sup> or OH<sup>-</sup> are released or bound. The lower the pH of a solution, the higher the concentration of H<sup>+</sup> (and the lower the concentration of OH<sup>-</sup>); the higher the pH, the lower the concentration of H<sup>+</sup> (and the higher the concentration of OH<sup>-</sup>).

pageData.text: All organisms, including microorganisms, have enzymes that are optimized to work best within a certain narrow pH range. Enzymes are responsible for driving metabolic reactions; thus, cellular activities, such as growth and reproduction, can only occur within a favorable range of pH values. Metabolic activity is inhibited at pH values that are too extreme for the organism.

Microorganisms are adapted to different <button class='glossary-text'>pH</button> levels depending on their usual environment. For example, bacteria living in the human mouth, where the pH is near <button class='glossary-text'>neutral</button>, grow best at a higher pH compared to certain bacteria living in the stomach, where the pH is approximately 1.5–3.5. Most microbes have their optimal growth under approximately neutral pH conditions (5.4–8.4) and are identified as <button class='glossary-text'>neutrophiles</button>. When microbes require a lower pH (0.1–5.4) they are known as <button class='glossary-text'>acidophiles</button>. Microbes thriving under <button class='glossary-text'>alkaline</button> conditions (8.4–11 or greater) are known as <button class='glossary-text'>alkaliphiles</button>. These microbes thrive under conditions of pH 9 and higher.

Because most microbes are neutrophiles, acidity has long been used to delay food spoilage caused by undesirable microorganisms. For example, the acidophilic bacteria used to make foods such as yogurt, cheese, and sauerkraut produce lactic acid as a byproduct of their metabolism. This acid will prevent the growth of other food-spoiling bacteria. Pickling can also be used to preserve food. This involves reducing the pH of the food by adding acid (such as vinegar, which contains acetic acid) to help slow bacterial growth.

Some microbes are tolerant of extreme pH values—they can grow and reproduce only under their preferred conditions but are able to survive under highly <button class='glossary-text'>acidic</button> and/or alkaline conditions, at least for a short time. Interestingly, the pH of the cytoplasm (internal cellular solution) of even extreme acidophiles or alkaliphiles is maintained at near-neutral levels. This is crucial for the survival of the microbe because certain key cellular components like DNA are extremely sensitive to changes in pH and lose their structure under strongly acidic or alkaline conditions. The cytoplasm of cellular microbes contains <button class='glossary-text'>buffers</button> to protect against large pH fluctuations. A buffer is a weakly acidic or alkaline compound that, when added to water, enables the resulting solution to resist large fluctuations in pH when a stronger acid or alkaline substance is introduced. Some microbes that live in extreme environments can also actively pump H<sup>+</sup> across their membranes to maintain a neutral cytoplasmic pH.
In this investigation, you will examine the responses of two different bacterial species to media of varying pH and determine which pH levels are inhibitory to growth.

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE). Refer to your instructions and videos on safe practices in the microbiology laboratory before beginning this investigation.
Isopropyl alcohol is flammable. Keep containers of isopropyl alcohol away from any heat or flame sources.

Chlorine bleach is a corrosive material. Use these materials near a source of running water that can be used as a safety eyewash or safety shower if any corrosive material comes in contact with skin or eyes. Do not use bleach in an area without proper ventilation, such as an open window or a bathroom with a fan.
Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity.

While wearing PPE, disinfect the work area with a 10% bleach solution (one part bleach to nine parts tap water) before starting the investigation. After completing your work, disinfect the work area with a 10% bleach solution followed by soap and water. Be sure to wear PPE during the disinfection and cleaning process.

typeBefore.text: Note: Use correct aseptic technique as you are working through this investigation. You may wish to review the Aseptic Technique and Use of Media investigation to refresh your memory. In particular, each time you remove the cap from a tube, the cap should be held, not placed on the work surface. The open mouth of each glass culture tube should be flamed as soon as the cap is removed and immediately before the cap is replaced.

Culture Recommendations: You will need very fresh broth cultures of E. coli and S. epidermidis for this investigation to be successful.
  • If you have a broth culture that is no more than two weeks days old, you may skip Preparation Steps 6–14
  • If you need to reactivate lyophilized cultures, follow the directions that came with the cultures using proper aseptic technique. You may wish to first review the video:

Both organisms will grow at room temperature; however, they will grow faster around 37° C (99° F). Once growth is apparent in the tryptic soy broth, you may skip Preparation Steps 6–14.
  • If you have a broth culture that is more than two weeks old, carry out all of the Preparation steps before proceeding to the activity.
Follow your instructor’s directions on whether to keep or discard your E. coli and S. epidermidis cultures at the end of this investigation.

pageData.text: Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and warm water. Dry your hands, then put on your PPE.
Disinfect the work surface, culture tube rack, and grease pencil or permanent marker with a 10% bleach solution.

Retrieve the needed media and, if applicable, lyophilized culture from storage. If the media have been stored in the refrigerator, allow them to sit for approximately 15 minutes to warm up to room temperature
Prepare your disposal jar by filling it with 70% isopropyl alcohol.
Obtain the liquid paraffin candle from the equipment set. Light the candle. Be sure to keep the candle a safe distance from the open container of isopropyl alcohol

Mix the contents of the reactivated or older E. coli culture by tapping the tube or rolling it between your palms. Aseptically transfer a loop of broth to a fresh tube of tryptic soy broth labeled “E. coli.”
Place the loop in the disposal jar; let it sit for at least 30 minutes, then discard the loop in the garbage.

Mix the contents of the reactivated or older S. epidermidis culture by tapping or rolling the tube between your palms. Aseptically transfer a loop of broth to a fresh tube of tryptic soy broth labeled “S. epidermidis.”
Place the loop in the disposal jar; let it sit for at least 30 minutes, then discard the loop in the garbage.
Extinguish the candle, and empty the alcohol from the disposal jar as described in Disposal and Cleanup on page 10. Keep the disposal jar for later use.
Incubate the inoculated broth tubes upright in the rack with their caps slightly loose. Both organisms will grow at room temperature; however, they will grow faster at around 37° C (99° F).
Disinfect the work area with a 10% bleach solution, remove your PPE, and wash your hands thoroughly.
Allow between 2 and 4 days of incubation for the broths to become turbid (cloudy), indicating that growth is occurring. Do not proceed until both cultures are growing well.

Note: Wait until your culture is turbid before proceeding to Activity 1.
Staphylococcus epidermidis is non-motile and the growth will be along the bottom of the tube. You will want to make sure the cells are in suspension. Escherichia coli is motile and the growth should be throughout the culture medium so they will appear turbid though they will also have more growth along the bottom of the tube.
Prepare to work as described in Steps 1–5.
Obtain all materials needed from the equipment set and culture materials, as well as those needed but not supplied.

In Activity 1, you will inoculate nutrient broth tubes at different with E. coli and S. epidermis. You will then incubate the tubes, photograph them, and document the amount of growth after 24 and 48 hours.

Using the grease pencil or permanent marker, label one nutrient broth tube of each for each of the different cultures with the name of the bacterium (e.g., take the two pH 3 tubes and label one “E. coli” and the other “S. epidermidis,” then repeat for the pH 7 and pH 9 tubes).

Using a fresh inoculating loop each time, aseptically inoculate the three tubes labeled “E. coli” with a loop of your “E. coli” broth culture. Repeat for the tubes labeled “S. epidermidis,” using your S. epidermidis broth culture. Place each loop into the disposal jar after use, and allow to sit for at least 30 minutes before discarding them according to the Disposal and Cleanup directions.
Let the cultures incubate with caps slightly loose for 24 hours.
Record the amount of growth for each treatment in Data Table 1. Take a photo of the culture tubes for each bacterium.
Incubate for another 24 hours (48 hours total). Record and document your results as before.
Note: If incubating at cooler temperatures, it may take five days or more for some strains to become significantly turbid.

To dispose of used inoculating loops, let them soak in the disposal jar with isopropyl alcohol for at least 30 minutes. Then, while wearing PPE, pour the alcohol down the drain with the faucet running. Allow the faucet to run for at least 30 seconds to dilute the alcohol. Wrap the loops in an opaque plastic bag, and put them in the garbage.
Keep your original broth cultures unless otherwise directed by your instructor.

To dispose of cultures that are no longer needed, put on your PPE, ensure adequate ventilation, and fill a lidded plastic container large enough to hold all the cultures with a 10% bleach solution. Hold each tube submerged in the bleach solution, and open it. Allow the cultures to soak in the bleach for at least 24 hours.

While wearing your PPE, pour the bleach down the drain with the faucet running. Let the faucet continue to run for at least 30 seconds to dilute the bleach. Place the disinfected tubes in an opaque plastic bag, and discard in the garbage.
